title: Airy, Modern House Hits Market in Oxfordshire, England
text:
It’s unlikely a house hunter looking for a piece of California modernism would head for the River Thames—but that’s right where they’ll find it.



An airy glass-lined pile replete with bubbling water features and built along a riverbank in Oxfordshire, England, has hit the market asking £2.895 million (US$3.6 million). Its clean, geometric lines and sun-drenched interiors are a far cry from the typical painted stucco and half-timbered houses that surround it in the hamlet of Burcot.



More: Brexit Fracas Puts Off U.K. House Sellers in September

Sam Selencky of architects Selencky Parsons designed the atypical country home, which spans 5,000 square feet across three floors, including a penthouse master suite with its own outdoor terrace. Mr. Selencky drew inspiration from the river, building it along a distinct horizontal plane to give the impression that it’s floating, according to the architect.



Decorative details fashioned from tropical Iroko wood add warmth to the home’s hardlines and minimal white palette, images of the home show.



“Water was a key part of the design,” noted the architect. “The river plot is so rare and we wanted to make sure the house was in constant dialogue with it.”



Besides a pool and the Thames itself, the home has a pond at the front that reflects light into bedrooms on the lower ground floor. A dock along the river provides space to moor a day boat, according to estate agents at The Modern House, which listed the home in September.



Sliding glass doors, a staple feature in the desert climate of Southern California but less so in cloudy England, peel away to create a seamless transition from the living room to the home’s limestone patio outside, according to the listing.



The property also includes a detached cedar-clad summer house, which sits closer to the river and provides an additional entertaining and recreational space.

Records show the current owners, a businessman and his wife, purchased the property in 2010 for £740,000 and replaced the existing red-brick bungalow with their modernist dream house in 2013, property records show.



The sellers, who could not be reached for comment, have dubbed the home “Isis View,” a nod to an ancient name for the River Thames and a term associated with Oxford University’s rowing team and its student magazine, according to the listing.
